fields.instructions: Enter a concise title (max 200 characters) that clearly reflects the purpose and scope of the project.
Select the primary sector/cluster relevant to this project, aligned with CERF sector classifications.
Indicate any secondary sector/cluster addressed by the project, if applicable.
Specify country and subnational locations (regions, districts, cities) where activities will be implemented.
Indicate UNHCR as the executing agency unless otherwise coordinated.
Provide total number of direct beneficiaries disaggregated by sex (men, women), age (boys, girls), and persons with disabilities. Avoid household or percentage-based figures.
List implementing sub-partners (e.g. NGOs, national/local actors) and describe their role where relevant.
Identify the UNHCR Field or Sub-Office responsible for implementation oversight.
Specify project duration: either 6 months for Rapid Response (RR) or 12 months for Underfunded Emergencies (UFE).
Indicate total amount requested from CERF and breakdown by sector(s). Budget must match Excel template.

sections.instructions: Summarize the crisis/emergency context, including the main humanitarian needs of the target population. Detail the target population by specifying who they are, where they are located, and their number. Describe key activities, grouped by sector (e.g., protection, shelter/NFIs). Ensure this summary does not duplicate text from the allocation strategy. Explain how the project will be catalytic/transformational and how its results will be sustainable beyond the CERF allocation period.

Complete the header table with precise information: 1) Country name  2) Clear, concise project title reflecting emergency nature 3) Exact budget amount  4) Primary sector/outcome  5) Realistic implementation period (typically 6-12 months) 6) Evidence-based beneficiary count 7) Specific Japanese policy priorities from that align with project

sections.section_name: 1. Summary of the Project and Background
sections.instructions: Provide compelling context: 1) Current humanitarian situation with specific data 2) Population needs analysis using {{needs}} variable 3) Clear project objectives 4) Specific activities planned 5) Quantifiable targets and indicators 6) Avoid multi-year planning language. Include the beneficiary table as provided without populating numbers.

Develop results framework: 1) Overall impact statement capturing project essence 2) For each outcome, write one paragraph describing activities and results with beneficiary numbers 3) For each outcome, specify 1-2 outputs with clear deliverables 4) For each output, create SMART indicators (Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound)

subsections.name: Overall Impact
subsections.instructions: Craft a powerful impact statement summarizing the transformative change expected from the project

subsections.name: Outcome
subsections.instructions: For each outcome area, describe activities and expected results with precise beneficiary numbers, following theory of change principles

subsections.name: Output
subsections.instructions: Define concrete deliverables for each outcome using action-oriented language

subsections.name: Indicator
subsections.instructions: Create SMART indicators for each output that are specific, measurable, achievable, relevant and time-bound

sections.instructions: Write persuasive justification with minimum 300 words per subsection. Each subsection must stand alone as a compelling argument for funding.

subsections.name: 3.1. Urgency
subsections.instructions: Demonstrate urgent need: 1) Recent events/changes in humanitarian situation 2) Data-supported scale and severity 3) Direct impact on population 4) Consequences of inaction 5) Why activities cannot wait for next fiscal year core contributions

subsections.name: 3.2. Unpredictability
subsections.instructions: Prove unpredictability: 1) Unforeseen incidents since April 2025 2) Why waiting until April 2026 is not feasible 3) Complex/volatile situation analysis 4) Recent exacerbating developments 5) Future risks and instability factors 6) Need for flexible funding

subsections.name: 3.3. Necessity
subsections.instructions: Align with Japanese priorities: 1) How project advances Japan's {{policy_priorities}} 2) Linkage to Humanitarian-Development Nexus 3) Focus on contributing to Japan's efforts rather than just alignment

subsections.name: 3.4. Un-substitutability
subsections.instructions: Prove UNHCR's unique role: 1) Why Japanese funding is irreplaceable 2) UNHCR's government relationships 3) Specialized know-how and capacity 4) Security/access advantages 5) Comparative advantage over other actors

sections.section_name: 4. Linkage with National, Regional and International Frameworks
sections.instructions: Demonstrate alignment: 1) National strategies and policies 2) Regional frameworks 3) International agreements 4) Host government support and citations 5) Relevant SDGs 6) Avoid repeating GOJ policy priorities

sections.section_name: 5. Cooperation with Japanese and Other Actors
sections.instructions: Detail partnerships: 1) Japanese collaboration (JICA, Japanese staff, NGO, company) 2) Other partnerships (government, local authorities, NGOs, UN agencies) 3) Coordination mechanisms 4) Value-added of each partnership

subsections.name: Japanese Actors
subsections.instructions: Focus on Japanese engagement: JICA collaboration, Japanese staff employment, NGO partnerships, and procurement from Japanese companies

subsections.name: Other Actors
subsections.instructions: Describe broader partnership ecosystem with governments, local authorities, and international organizations

sections.instructions: Specifically address how the project supports Japan's Priority_Areas with concrete examples and clear linkages to Japanese strategic objectives
Outline specific visibility activities that will recognize Japan's contribution: 1) Media engagement 2) Public recognition 3) Reporting requirements 4) Branding guidelines implementation

Reproduce the standard text exactly as provided without modification: 1) Monitoring and Evaluation procedures 2) Audit framework 3) Reporting timeline and requirements:
                **8.1. Monitoring and Evaluation**: UNHCR adheres to a comprehensive annual programme cycle within a multi-year strategy, where monitoring and evaluation are intrinsic parts of the Results-Based Programme Management cycle. Throughout the year, progress of activities is monitored based on the M&E plan, which includes field visits, missions, and regular consultations with community members, partners, service providers, and other stakeholders.
                **8.2. Audit**: UNHCR is audited in accordance with the UN Financial Regulations and the UNHCR Financial Rules. All financial transactions and related activities covered by these regulations and rules are subject to audit by internal auditors and the United Nations Board of Auditors. UNHCR's annual financial statements are published on the Board of Auditors' website here.
                **8.3. Reporting**: UNHCR will submit a final narrative report, including a financial component, three months after the completion of the project.
Provide complete office contact information: 1) Full name of responsible officer 2) Official title 3) Exact office name and location

Create detailed budget table: 1) Structure by outcome areas 2) List outputs under each outcome 3) Describe activities for each output 4) Assign budget amounts at output level 5) Include ISC  indirect support costs 6) Ensure total matches budget 7) Right-align all numbers 8) Add coordination levy note

table_structure.footer: Include this note 'The 1% coordination levy is not applicable' at the end of the table.

language_restrictions: Avoid phrases indicating multi-year planning continuity
Do not use 'as a continuation from the previous year'
formatting_requirements: Right-align all numerical values in budget table
Maintain exact table structures as specified
strategic_emphasis: Focus on how project advances Japan's policy priorities
Demonstrate why Japanese funding is essential
Show UNHCR's unique capacity and access
